{'scenario_context': 'On a weekday evening in their small shared apartment, [Agent 1] asks [Agent 2] to set aside 15 minutes to align on personal-care habits in shared spaces after a building notice cited recurring odors, damp towels, and hair-clogged drains ahead of tomorrow’s inspection. A mutual friend is staying over this weekend, raising reputational stakes. [Agent 1] has prepared a neutral, inclusive checklist (shower timing, towel rotation, laundry frequency, handling sweaty gym clothes, acceptable fragrance use) and wants to invite [Agent 2]’s perspective without blame. Complicating matters, [Agent 1] has fragrance sensitivity that triggers migraines, while [Agent 2] has been relying on heavy body spray due to back-to-back shifts, exam stress, and delayed laundry access. [Agent 2] feels vulnerable to judgment and plans to frame lapses as situational while staying cordial. {'scenario_context': 'In a workplace complaint intake at a midsize company, [Agent 1] (victim advocate) and [Agent 2] (neutral investigator) meet just before and during an interview with an employee who reported being repeatedly interrupted in meetings, excluded from key email threads, and made the subject of teasing by a senior colleague. Both expect cooperation and aim to quickly converge on a fair, actionable understanding to guide remedies.', 'explanation': 'This setup makes the shared goal (seeking justice) concrete while aligning individual goals: [Agent 1] ensures the harmed party’s impact is centered and minimization is challenged; [Agent 2] protects procedural fairness through neutral summaries, specific questions, and bracketing speculation. The Easy difficulty is reflected in mutual respect, clear ground rules, and expected cooperation, keeping tensions low and objectives attainable.'}

[Agent 2], the Legal Mediator, is a neutral third party appointed to oversee the process, emphasizing adherence to formal procedures and equitable legal standards. Both agents must collaborate to reach a resolution, but tensions are high as [Agent 1] believes the victim's suffering should drive the outcome, while [Agent 2] insists that strict procedural fairness is necessary to uphold systemic justice. The 'Hard' difficulty arises from the inherent tension between restorative and retributive justice frameworks."}

{'scenario_context': 'On a weekday evening in their small shared apartment, [Agent 1] asks [Agent 2] to set aside 15 minutes to align on personal-care habits in shared spaces after a building notice cited recurring odors, damp towels, and hair-clogged drains ahead of tomorrow’s inspection. A mutual friend is staying over this weekend, raising reputational stakes. [Agent 1] has prepared a neutral, inclusive checklist (shower timing, towel rotation, laundry frequency, handling sweaty gym clothes, acceptable fragrance use) and wants to invite [Agent 2]’s perspective without blame. Complicating matters, [Agent 1] has fragrance sensitivity that triggers migraines, while [Agent 2] has been relying on heavy body spray due to back-to-back shifts, exam stress, and delayed laundry access. [Agent 2] feels vulnerable to judgment and plans to frame lapses as situational while staying cordial. With prior passive-aggressive notes eroding trust and limited time before the inspection, they must agree on immediate, concrete hygiene routines tonight.', 'explanation': 'Hard difficulty stems from identity threat, time pressure, and high evaluation stakes (inspection, guest), plus incompatible constraints (fragrance sensitivity vs reliance on sprays) and a history of indirect conflict. The setup foregrounds attribution dynamics: [Agent 1] aims to avoid dispositional blame and co-create norms; [Agent 2] seeks to preserve a positive self-image via situational attributions while remaining receptive—inviting self-serving bias, fundamental attribution error, and face-saving tensions.'}

{'scenario_context': 'In a workplace complaint intake at a midsize company, [Agent 1] (victim advocate) and [Agent 2] (neutral investigator) meet just before and during an interview with an employee who reported being repeatedly interrupted in meetings, excluded from key email threads, and made the subject of teasing by a senior colleague. Prior statements from others frame the behavior as a “miscommunication during deadline stress” and “just his joking style.” The two agents align on how to conduct a calm, fact-focused interview that centers the harmed employee’s experience while preserving procedural neutrality. [Agent 1] plans to reframe any neutralizing or deflective remarks into impact-focused language and to call out minimization if it arises. [Agent 2] plans to neutrally summarize each claim, establish a clear timeline, ask targeted clarifying questions, and defer any speculation about motives, keeping the focus on what can be verified. Ground rules are simple and agreed upon: pause to rephrase if minimizing language appears, separate perceptions from confirmed facts, and document next steps. Both expect cooperation and aim to quickly converge on a fair, actionable understanding to guide remedies.', 'explanation': 'This setup makes the shared goal (seeking justice) concrete while aligning individual goals: [Agent 1] ensures the harmed party’s impact is centered and minimization is challenged; [Agent 2] protects procedural fairness through neutral summaries, specific questions, and bracketing speculation. The scenario highlights attribution dynamics (situational explanations like stress, dispositional rationalizations like “just his style”) and positions the agents to negotiate these attributions constructively. The Easy difficulty is reflected in mutual respect, clear ground rules, and expected cooperation, keeping tensions low and objectives attainable.'}
